target_title: .ics event importer dialog previews floating time events as if they were UTC (but imports them correctly)

note.body:
> **Floating time zone:** In the case of a correctly defined floating time zone event, we should display it in the same way as in the event editor. It is planned to display the time zone in brackets, e.g. 8:45 (UTC+1) or 8:45 (floating time zone).
>
> **Correctly defined time zone:** Display the time zone in brackets if it does not equal local time zone. Do not show the time zone if it equals local time zone.

Do you agree with the handling of recognized time zones I proposed?

**Regarding the handling of corrupt data:**

I agree with you that there will always be corrupted data and we need to process it. My main point is that, by default, if we don't have a defined way of handling the imported data, we should return a user-visible error and refuse the import. Take this file ([RDV_France_Travail\_-\_Rendez-vous_conseil (broken).ics](/uploads/ce1e258b6fd3de1737223842252435b6/RDV_France_Travail\_-\_Rendez-vous_conseil__broken\_.ics)) as an example. I just edited your example above with a text editor and inserted some random letters in the date field of the file (`DTSTART:abc20250119T084500`). It shows up in the event editor without the start field, but the user is not prevented from importing it. I didn't get an error and I assume that I now have a corrupted event in the backend that just isn't being displayed.

However, we could of course define specific error cases and handle them. And for some common, well-scoped errors, we could show a UI that allows the user to fix the error. I just don't see the special case here where the timezone needs to be set manually. Please open a separate issue if you can define a well-scoped error  that could be fixed by manually selecting a time zone.

target_title: .ics event importer dialog previews floating time events as if they were UTC (but imports them correctly)

note.body:
Regarding #1110:

> **Incorrect data:** […] we should just display a warning and not import it.
> 
> […] I think we should not add the ability to fix broken .ics events because it will add a lot of code and UI complexity.

In theory maybe, but in practice we live in a complex world of broken stuff everywhere, where we must be liberal in what we accept, and strict in what we output ([Postel's law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robustness_principle)).

I think what we are seeing here is unfortunately a fairly common situation; there are countless servers/platforms (or even Outlook) giving you such ambiguous files. By not offering a timezone override UI, we're essentially telling the users to:
1. cancel their import operation,
2. open the file manager,
3. open the files in a plaintext editor
4. manually fix every event in the .ics themselves (with trial-and-error, and knowing exactly how timezones are supposed to be encoded in the format)
5. try to import again and "hope the software likes it"

…I don't think this is helpful to users. Only putting up a stopsign and refusing to import would just be frustrating* the user with no practical immediate solution.

In theory I could imagine the user using the event editor dialog's timezones capabilities to fix things post-facto, but:
* that isn't as convenient as fixing it directly on import;
* it does not scale if you are importing 50 events at once from one (or multiple) .ics file(s) and then have to go edit each one individually (multiply that work by two, because you have to set the beginning and end time's timezones);
* the user may not even get that far. If the import dialog gives them apparently wrong information, they may not import the events at all

> we should do our best to automatically interpret the data

So far I have come to the conclusion that we [cannot](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/-/issues/1110#note_2306287), unfortunately (and if it was that easy, I bet Evolution would already be doing it; Milan stated that Evolution does not want to do that).

---

<details><summary>Click to expand: personal user story (real world scenario)</summary>

*: **Personal user story:** I encountered a similar kind of situation where I had to do  manual editing nonsense a month ago, when Swiss Airlines' website gave me .ics files with incorrect times: I spent a solid hour just trying to wrap my head around correctly fixing the dates and times for 4 flight segments crossing multiple days and multiple timezones. I had to use [Meld](https://meldmerge.org) and it took me at least 10 tries, with lots of frustration.

If _I_ can't figure this out in two minutes, how are normies going to do it? "You should tell Swiss to fix their .ics files" is not realistically going to happen: try explaining that to non-geek booking agents over the phone, who have no incentive nor power to solve this technical problem, _and_ it's not even the airline making that .ics mistake, it's generated by some other third-party software with a generic name that you can't even find on the web…
</details>

target_title: .ics event importer dialog previews floating time events as if they were UTC (but imports them correctly)

note.body:
**Incorrect data:** In the case of an event with data that cannot be automatically interpreted correctly and unambiguously, we should just display a warning and not import it. At the same time, of course, we should do our best to automatically interpret the data. So if there are alternative ways to define a timezone according to the specification, such as MET (=UTC+1), this should be covered in the backend. I think we should not add the ability to fix broken .ics events because it will add a lot of code and UI complexity.

**Floating time zone:** In the case of a correctly defined floating time zone event, we should display it in the same way as in the event editor. It is planned to display the time zone in brackets, e.g. 8:45 (UTC+1) or 8:45 (floating time zone).

**Correctly defined time zone:** Display the time zone in brackets if it does not equal local time zone. Do not show the time zone if it equals local time zone.

target_title: .ics event importer dialog previews floating time events as if they were UTC (but imports them correctly)

note.body:
> in the current implementation, it's unable to differentiate between floating time events (like this one) and events with wrong/unknown timezones

Then _make it_ have that distinction then ;)

As I understand it, here (the first case) it is just a view/rendering issue (where the view is the import dialog), not a data/backend issue. It should be able to distinguish the two aspects, like the other views (month view, week view, etc.) can; i.e. you render/preview the floating time at the system's local time, while keeping it floating when encoding/importing it.

> We can change this behavior to use the local timezone in both cases

In this 2nd case, I think you definitely want to prompt the user to explicitly confirm with a timezones picker UI because [we cannot guess it](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/-/issues/1110#note_2306287) for them; we can't assume local time nor UTC, nor the true meaning of any short timezone code... @philippsauberz might have ideas for how to handle this with the UI?

target_title: Webcalendars or .ics files vaguely referencing a custom but nonexistent/undefined virtual timezone cause recurring event's floating time to be offset by multiple hours (interpreted as UTC)

note.body:
Re-reading this again, also with my new perspective on floating time events: any automatic interpretation might be wrong, as Milan pointed out. So we must not assume UTC nor floating time when the app doesn't understand the timezone.

My understanding of Milan's comments in #1110, and also from thinking some more about it, is that it also _is_ impossible to reverse-guess the [timezone city/country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones#List) (ex.: "Asia/Bangkok") just from the [timezone abbreviation code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_time_zone_abbreviations), because a code may cover multiple cities/countries.  
For example, `EET` covers `Asia/Famagusta`, `Asia/Gaza`, `Asia/Hebron`, `Egypt`, `Europe/Athens`, `Europe/Bucharest`, ` Europe/Helsinki`, `Europe/Kyiv`, etc.

I think then what we must do instead is show a GUI to ask the user to pick a valid timezone to correct the event; like @titouanreal's timezone picker widgets from !516, but in the import dialog, presuming they are made in such a way that they can be reused easily across the app's various dialogs when needed.

---

<details><summary>Click to expand: Why bother providing a GUI for this?</summary>

From my reply to @philippsauberz in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/-/issues/1327#note_2306758 :

In practice we live in a complex world of broken stuff everywhere, where we must be liberal in what we accept, and strict in what we output ([Postel's law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robustness_principle)).

I think what we are seeing here is unfortunately a fairly common situation; there are countless servers/platforms (or even Outlook) giving you such ambiguous files.

By not offering a timezone override UI, we'd essentially be telling the users to cancel the whole import operation, open the ics files in a plaintext editor and manually fix every event in the .ics themselves (which requires extremely arcane knowledge and the ability to not get confused across dates and times on multiple timezones)… which is not helpful to users.
</details>

target_title: Simple swiping gestures for scrolling the new month view on touchscreens

note.body:
I see two possible variants from a design perspective:

**Simple without date range selection:**

- Swiping up and down with a single finger scrolls the month view. The day cell where the swipe gesture starts does not get highlighted.
- Tapping with a single finger highlights the day cell below and opens the quick add dialog.

**Advanced with date range selection:**

- Swiping up and down with a single finger scrolls the month view. The day cell where the swipe gesture starts does not get highlighted.
- Long press with a single finger highlights the day cell below. Subsequently dragging the finger selects the date range. Releasing the finger opens the quick add popover with the selected range.

Long press is an established pattern used in GNOME typically to simulate a right click with touch. We don’t need any right click menu in the week and month view and can use this gesture for starting a drag operation to select the date range. I’m unsure about technical difficulties though.

Calendars list GtkPopoverMenu does not show up when calendar name length exceeds width of the screen

note.body:
OK, I found out how to reproduce this on any screen: create a local calendar with a really unreasonably long calendar name, so that it breaks even on a 2560px-wide desktop screen, for example this nearly 450-characters-long standard _Lorem Ipsum_ text:

> Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.

The calendars management dialog can handle it because it wraps lines, but the PopoverMenu widget can't. The Event Editor (and Event Importer) dialogs are not affected, because they use a ComboRow widget, whose dropdown menu widget does ellipsizing when one of the items is about to exceed the screen width.

I'm not sure how to cleanly handle this. Is there a way to have automatic ellipsization with PopoverMenu widgets or will this break horribly? I wouldn't want to ellipsize the text unless we _have_ to, i.e. only if the calendar name length would exceed the physical screen width.

---

**Note to testers:** if you create a calendar with such a lengthy name, you won't be able to open the menu anymore, so your only way to access the calendars management dialog again (to edit/delete that calendar) will be to use the `Ctrl+Alt+M` keyboard shortcut.

target_title: .ics event importer dialog previews floating time events as if they were UTC (but imports them correctly)

note.body:
Yes, you're right, according to the RFC5545 (section [3.3.5](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5545#section-3.3.5), FORM 1) events without indication of timezone (not using the "TZID" property parameter nor the "Z" letter at the end of the date-time) are not bound to any timezone and should be interpreted in the system's local time and the GNOME Calendar is doing this correctly currently, with the exception of the import dialog as we see in this issue.

What happens with the import dialog, as @felipeanibal described, is that, in the current implementation, it's unable to differentiate between floating time events (like this one) and events with wrong/unknown timezones (like the one in issue #1110, as you suggested, where the system doesn't have the definition of the timezone provided in the ICS file) and ends up setting both to UTC, this is why the problem here is related with #1110, we couldn't think in a way to deal with these two cases separately[^1].

We can change this behavior to use the local timezone in both cases, fixing the expected result for this current issue, but also assigning the local TZ to events with incorrect timezone definitions, for which there is no clear rule in the RFC. This last case was discussed with Milan in issue #1110 ([this](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/-/issues/1110#note_2046441) and [this](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/-/issues/1110#note_2207566) comments) and you also [suggested](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/-/issues/1110#note_2206647) displaying a warning in the GUI, which I think would be ideal, but it's still a choice, not a standard. If you agree, I think we can follow this suggestions and use the local timezone in both cases, and then work on a warning (maybe in other issue). What do you think?

[^1]: We're open to suggestions on how to change this in the code :). The function responsible for generating the event that is displayed in the import dialog is the `gcal_date_time_from_icaltime` in the file [src/utils/gcal-date-time-utils.c](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/-/blob/main/src/utils/gcal-date-time-utils.c?ref_type=heads#L218).

Allow pinned notifications

note.body: Thinking about it further: If I am not mistaken, I think GNOME Calendar does not even emit notifications at all, rather leaving that job to Evolution Data Server (otherwise you'd end up with double notifications!)… and in this context, the notification's urgency is presumably not something the app is allowed to configure on the basis of a per-calendar property either (unless @mcrha tells me that is the case). If this level of granularity ever happens, it would probably be after the calendaring notifications become part of GNOME Shell territory in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/issues/155, but I don't know if that kind of flexibility would be in the plans yet (it would be https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/issues/3898).

target_title: Allow pinned notifications

note.body: In any case, I think George's general stance on such things is that the setting should belong in the "GNOME Settings" app's notifications panel, and not in the app itself (this is why, for instance, GNOME Calendar does not have a "preferences" dialog, only per-calendar properties). In this way I think this is related to https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/issues/5693 and https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/issues/3631.

target_title: event-editor: Allow the user to set timezones

note.body:
The details of design aspects are discussed in #1319. I got some feedback from other members of the design team [there](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/-/issues/1319#note_2300780). I think in the scope of this MR we should include the following changes:

- Show the time zone in the label of the entry row instead of the button label. UTC+X is ok now, we can show the city later.
- Remove the time zone button from the time entry row.
- Add a time zone action row to the time popover. Clicking it opens the existing time zone dialog.
- Time zone picker dialog:
  * Make the search bar fill the width of the dialog.
  * Add placeholder text "Search locations" to the search bar.
  * Apply the time zone and close the dialog when an item is clicked.
  * Remove the Cancel and Select buttons and add the normal "x" for closing the dialog

That is not exactly proper though. As per the [Gio docs](https://docs.gtk.org/gio/enum.NotificationPriority.html):

> For urgent notifications, or notifications that require a response in a short space of time (for example phone calls or emergency warnings).

Though do note that the [spec itself](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/notification-spec/latest/urgency-levels.html) doesn’t have such an opinion.

I would imagine the "UTC±13" shortform to be used only on mobile-style window widths if space is too constrained to show a city name. On the desktop, when plenty of space is available, I would much prefer being able to see cities or regions (but not the continent! That's meaningless.), like "Los Angeles" and "Buenos Aires", or "Pacific" (or "California") and "Argentina" (see the [list of timezone names](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones)).

Also, an alternative to the pure UTC±13 shortform is to use timezone codes when space is too constrained, such as "PDT" and "ART" (see the [list of timezones abbreviations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_time_zone_abbreviations); there are some caveats mentioned on that page though).

note.body:
OK, with those sample files I can reproduce the problem, with those events being considered as if they were on December 24th by the sidebar, whereas they really should be on December 23rd (like in the month view), when viewed with a north-american system timezone like the US east coast one (i.e. New York City):

| Actual (incorrect) behavior | Expected behavior |
| -- | -- |
| ![image](/uploads/6bd6f803be0d57c02ff426eee5c54c6a/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/06b40f1d882fbed3d5e4552ec49cd36f/image.png) |

Those events as provided are encoded as UTC (ending with "Z") in the file format, and in UTC they happen to start at midnight (a.k.a. 19h eastern) and end at 2 AM (a.k.a. 21h eastern)... for example, inside the "🏒 Philadelphia Flyers @ Pittsburgh Penguins" event's .ics file, we see:

```
DTSTART:20241224T000000Z
DTEND:20241224T020000Z
```

The problem also happens if you set your system timezone to Los Angeles, California, but does _not_ occur if you set your system timezone to Paris, France (because in that case the event actually starts in the morning of the 24th in European and African timezones, so the problem goes unnoticed):

![image](/uploads/63fedbac7c9004998231dd1d9c481b11/image.png)

@khemicalkoder, you had really brilliant solutions to the various similar issues around sorting and header splitting in the sidebar previously. Would you happen to have an idea about this one too, possibly related to UTC midnight interpretation?

target_title: .ics event importer dialog previews floating time events as if they were UTC (but imports them correctly)

note.body:
I understand your question and agree with your general idea when it comes to "incorrect" timezones like #1110 (maybe you got this mixed with that one?), but in the sample here (especially JLuc's simple event) it's not that there is an invalid/imprecise timezone, it is that there is _no timezone at all,_ which I understand to be a true floating event, right?

For instance, this is the entirety of JLuc's ics file:

```config
BEGIN:VCALENDAR
VERSION:2.0
PRODID:-//www.truc.f//Mes-RDV
NAME:TEST Rendez-vous
CALSCALE:GREGORIAN
BEGIN:VEVENT
DTSTART:20250119T084500
DTEND:20250119T123000
SUMMARY: Test Rendez-vous habituel
DESCRIPTION:Bonjour,\n\nRendez-vous lundi 20/01/2025 à 08:45
LOCATION:COMME DHABITUDE.
END:VEVENT
END:VCALENDAR
```

No "TZ" anywhere, no "Z", so I think that means floating time? If so, then it should be previewed at the system's local time (what this ticket is about) and imported as a floating time event (this is already done, as far as I can tell).

target_title: .ics event importer dialog previews floating time events as if they were UTC (but imports them correctly)

note.body:
The standard behaviour in most of the calendar when dealing with unkown/incorrect timezones is to convert them to UTC time. When the timezone is not specified, on the other hand, it means that it is a floating time event, and the calendar displays it in local time (as we implemented solving issue #171).

On the import dialog however, there is no difference between incorrect/undefined timezones (like typos) and floating time events. The code of the import dialog converts both to UTC. It is easy to change this behaviour so that both events with incorrect timezones and floating time events become local time, but it is more challenging to differentiate between those two scenarios.

What do you think should be the behaviour when dealing with incorrect timezones? Should they be represented as floating time events or in UTC (or in another way)?

Me and @otavio.ols think that perhaps a good idea would be show an error message when the timezone is incorrect. An option would be to treat them as floating time and at the same time display the error message, to let the user know that something might be incorrect. We were not sure, however, what would be the best way to show the error.

target_title: Update design of event editor schedule section

note.body:
I brought this up in the design call and got some feedback from @aday and @kramo. My main takeaways were:
- Avoid multiple suffix buttons. The time zone should be integrated into the time picker popover. Then we'd only have the clock button in the row.
- Keep the default edit icon of the entry row. This works for me when we only have one suffix button.
- We can display the weekday in addition to the numeric date in the date entry while it is not focused, and change the string to the numeric date only when the entry becomes focused. This way we have a more reader-friendly time display. At the same time we also make it clear that only numbers are parsed by switching to numeric date only.

note.body:
Well, this is pretty ancient to me too. I guess adding a timezone selector goes a long way.

What I gather from my initial report, the local timezone would be lost when getting back from 24h and would be set to UTC.

I think what happened with the initial dialog back then is the following.

1. Set a timed event, this was set with the local TZ.
2. Check the all-day button, the timed event start & end time would be preserved in the dialog (not sure if it is/was retained after the dialog closes).
3. Uncheck the all-day button, the timed event start & end time would be re-instated, but with UTC as TZ.

This would shift the exact time of the event between step 1 & 3 depending on what TZ you are in.

Oh and thanks for working on this, Calendar already was sweet, but it has come another long way lately!

target_title: Switching a time-based event to all day loses its timezone information

note.body:
@mschraal this was originally your bug report, in case you want to clarify your stance on the question above :)

That said, in one of the ancient comments above (nearly 8 years ago), while reviewing @igaldino's patch, @feaneron said:

> […] there's nothing we can really do. There's no way to store the previous timezone with libical.

…so it sounds like the actionable part is about ensuring we are preserving the timezone information "until the user has hit Save", after which it should be presumed lost forever due to storage format limitations, if I understand correctly. Maybe your branch already does this (?), but until now there had been no way to even test that basic "keep it while the dialog is still active" approach, because there was no GUI for it.

So… the format reportedly does not have a "history" of timezones, yet I wonder if there really is no way to keep the only last previously used timezone stored within the event's metadata even if unused after it switches from `DATE-TIME` to `DATE` type? Searching through https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5545 it wasn't entirely clear to me, but I think I may have found something about it (if I did not misunderstand the context it is in, on page 27) that confirms it is not allowed:

> The `TZID` property parameter MUST NOT be applied to DATE properties and DATE-TIME or TIME properties whose time values are specified in UTC.
> 
> The use of local time in a DATE-TIME or TIME value without the `TZID` property parameter is to be interpreted as floating time, regardless of the existence of `VTIMEZONE` calendar components in the iCalendar object.
> 
> For more information, see the sections on the value types DATE- TIME and TIME.

note.body:
I understand the use case of entering an event without defining a duration. But I agree with the reasons already mentioned why this is not just about adding another event case to our user interface. If we implement this while other applications do not support it (even if the spec allows it), it will result in data loss when it is synchronized. In my opinion, this trade-off is not worth it.

However, we can do our best to support this use case. It's already possible to enter the same start and end time in the GNOME calendar and other calendar apps support that too. All we would have to do is fix bug #409, which causes events with a duration of 0 minutes to be displayed incorrectly in the week view.

target_title: RFC 5545 compliance: Calendar should allow events that only have a start time and no end time, but are also not all-day events

note.body:
The problem with that is that we are beholden to the file format and server interchange/interoperability standards, in addition to typical GUI representation tradeoffs. We can't just invent anything that "replicates paper"; digital calendaring tools are more rigidly structured than "thoughts drawn on paper".

From what I am seeing here so far, the closest thing I would propose for your usecase is to continue to create uncertain events as "all day" (I do the same thing), and then later convert them via the event editor, or via drag-and-drop if someone can contribute a patch to implement #278.

note.body:
The GUI part of the Evolution does not let you unset the end time. A workaround is to set it to the nearest minute from the start time, like to the same or the next minute of the start.

The GUI part of the Evolution shows "zero-length events" at their start time (as shown in the screenshot above). In fact, any event shorter than the time division in the Day/Work Week views is always shown with this minimum height, thus the text (one line of it) can be read. The tiny white column between the time and the event on the screenshot is used to show the actual time the event uses. Having the event for 15 minutes it'll be half of the row height for the 30 minutes division.

This is not about the evolution-data-server (eds) supporting it or not, for read/write from/to the server it does not care, it just passes the data over (CalDAV and On This Computer speaking). Passing it through the ECalClientView and similar functions works, otherwise you won't see it in the Evolution nor gnome-calendar, right? The main problem is how to visualize these events in the GUI, not much how to work with then in the background (there are some tricky parts, yes, but it had been fixed/added to the eds long ago - bugs exist for it).

note.body:
@jfft @TitouanReal Many thanks for your tests and thoughts on this!

For me, there is actually a real, everyday use case.
When I make private appointments with people, I often don't organise them within a certain time frame.
For example, I meet up with a friend for a walk or to cook dinner in the evening. What I then need is a start time and possibly the place where we will start our appointment. However, I don't need to know and usually don't know in advance whether our walk will last 45 minutes or 2.5 hours. And I still think it's important that the appointment is visible in my calendar and that I can set a reminder for this event.

And of course I do not only have appointments that are not time-bound, but also appointments where time slots play an essential role or are given. That's why I'm in favour of the GNOME calendar being able to reflect both realities of my life.

target_title: No visual feedback when a date can not be parsed in the date and time entry of the event editor dialog

note.body:
1. type 2
2. type /
3. type 3
4. separator / is automatically added because there is no valid month starting with 3 followed by another number (that would only be the case with 1 that could be followed by 0, 1, 2)
5. type 2024

A more precise description of the behavior:
Instead of always ignoring separators, the autocomplete feature allows you to manually insert separators when appropriate. Separators are added automatically when no other number can be entered because two numbers have already been added or no number can be added that would result in a valid date. Consecutive entries of separators are ignored.

target_title: RFC 5545 compliance: Calendar should allow events that only have a start time and no end time, but are also not all-day events

note.body:
At first I wondered, _"How can this **possibly** make sense?"_ (and there's even @devrtz's #660 that goes directly up against this), but page 53 of the [RFC 5545](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5545) spec _does_ actually say:

> […] The `DTEND` property for a `VEVENT` calendar component specifies the non-inclusive end of the event.  
> * For cases where a `VEVENT` calendar component specifies a `DTSTART` property with a `DATE` value type but no `DTEND` nor `DURATION` property, the event's duration is taken to be one day.  
> * For cases where a `VEVENT` calendar component specifies a `DTSTART` property with a `DATE-TIME` value type but no `DTEND` property, **the event ends on the same calendar date and time of day specified by the `DTSTART` property.**

For testing, I created a time-based event and edited it with gedit to remove the `DTEND` line, presuming that is sufficient to be a valid sample: [issue-1321-datetime-sample-event.ics](/uploads/80527ef7cf08935f4e2aafdb6eff4a11/issue-1321-datetime-sample-event.ics)

With this sample, we can see that GNOME Calendar (shown on the left below) indeed _represents_ it as all-day in the views, unlike Evolution (shown on the right):

![image](/uploads/92be047b04e11157fdc26e2da32f5d20/image.png)

Is it enough for GNOME Calendar to just be able to parse and render such events when loading/importing them, or do you _really_ need to be able to also _create_ such events within GNOME Calendar's event editor GUI (I honestly have a hard time imagining why anyone would want that)? If the latter, this means that @teams/design will need to take this into account in the UI design for #1319, and @titouanreal in its implementation in !507.

target_title: No visual feedback when a date can not be parsed in the date and time entry of the event editor dialog

note.body: What if you want to enter 2/3/2024 ? Do you have to type 02/03/2024? Maybe we could accept a `tab` or `space` key press to go to the next field.

target_title: No visual feedback when a date can not be parsed in the date and time entry of the event editor dialog

note.body:
I thought we could do even better than providing visual feedback **after** the user enters an invalid format. What if we actually guided the user to enter the correct format **while** they were typing?

My idea is that we could do something like this:

- Use the date format defined in settings.
- Restrict the date entry to accept numbers only.
- If the user enters an unsupported character the orange warning style class is applied to the AdwEntryRow. The warning style class is removed again when the next supported character is entered.
- Enforce the correct date format using some kind of autocomplete that inserts the separators. If the user enters the separators they would just get ignored because they have already been inserted automatically.

For example if you want to enter 11.12.2024 (format depending on system settings):

1. type 11 --\> 11
2. the separator is added automatically --\> 11.
3. (optionally enter the separator, but it will be ignored)
4. type 12 --\> 11.12
5. the separator is added automatically --\> 11.12.
6. (optionally enter the separator, but it will be ignored)
7. type 2024 --\> 11.12.2024

So either typing "11122024" or "11.12.2024" would be possible.

This approach would also allow us to reintroduce **showing** the weekday in the entry. We could display "Wednesday, 12/11/2024" in the entry. This might make the user think they can enter a weekday at first, but they would get immediate feedback that this is not possible if they started typing any non-numeric character.

@bertob What do you think? This is a relatively simple solution to start doing something like the autocomplete you had in mind. I think we could start with this and expand on it when we have a proper design for something more sophisticated.

This was discussed with @jfft on matrix with the following consensus:
- **Changes do not get propagated to the picker widgets:** -> needs to be fixed in this MR
- **It uses full words in the text input field**: -> change to numeric dates only in this MR. We can come up with fancier formatting and parsing in a follow-up.

target_title: Use callbacks to apply calendar settings changes

note.body:
This instant-apply behavior seems to make sense from a functional standpoint, and I see no huge drawbacks while doing some light testing.

There is one issue though: **instant-applying the name changes is hammering the CPU** because you are doing it in realtime. You can even see it lagging if you type fast enough (or press-and-hold repeat characters). Much like search, there is no reason to do this (or anything related to high input, eventually) faster than once per 500-750 miliseconds.
* Ideally I'd like that to be addressed to ensure good performance and lower power consumption. Unfortunately, since it's not a `SearchEntry` widget, I doubt that GTK/libadwaita would provide you with a convenience timer delay property like `search-delay`...
* Alternatively, maybe the name change could/should still apply only on exit instead of in realtime, because it's not going to be seen in the UI behind the dialog anyway.

target_title: event-editor-schedule-section: redesign

note.body:
I was able to find a few issues with the current implementation of the date field and the time field:

* [ ] **No visual feedback for (in)valid values**  
Right now if you type a date it doesn't understand (ex: `thursday`, `jeudi`, `tomorrow`, `12`, etc.) it not only won't parse it, but also it won't visually let you know that there is a problem (ex: no red surrounding border for example).  
Technically `main` doesn't have that either, however it becomes a bigger problem here because of the next point...

* [ ] **It uses full words in the text input field,** instead of formatted dates  
It wouldn't be a problem if we had flexible parsing, syntax hints, and realtime visual feedback for validation, but as it currently stands it is difficult to guess the correct format, so whenever the widget gets focused out or the picker widget is used, it will override the value you typed, and since there is no validation visual feedback (previous point above) then you're throwing away the user's work without warning them

* [x] **Changes do not get propagated to the picker widgets**  
If you change the timestamp by replacing `16:30` by `16:33` in the text field by typing, when you click (or press `Tab` then `Spacebar`) the time picker button on the right, the spinners indicate `16:30`. The same probably applies to the date picker too.

target_title: Update design of event editor schedule section

note.body:
Latest design iteration:

![DateTimeEntryRows_suffixes](/uploads/667def1194d8aebc366b913839beb3ce/DateTimeEntryRows_suffixes.png)

source:[DateTimeEntryRows_suffixes.svg](/uploads/cf49f2baaf1a4ef673f3e621bfc24d45/DateTimeEntryRows_suffixes.svg)

- Date and time entry are based on AdwEntryRow and allow direct keyboard input.
- The mini calendar date picker is moved to a popover that can be opened by clicking the suffix calendar button in the date row.
- Time zones can be displayed and changed using the suffix button with the globe symbolic in the time row. If the time zone of the event is the local time zone, only the globe button is displayed. If the time zone is different, a label is displayed next to the icon.
- The time zone can be changed from the popover that opens when clicking the suffix button with the globe symbolic.
- The spin rows for changing the time are removed. This eliminates the need for a popover and associated suffix button in the time row. To make it easier to enter the time on mobile and touch, the input purpose of the time entry can be set to numbers only, so that a special layout of the on-screen keyboard can be displayed.

note.body:
I was able to track down the call graph from Gnome Calendar to the dialog about trust certificate.

In gcal-manager.c, `e_trust_prompt_run_for_source` is called. Then in EDS, it calls `e_trust_prompt_run_with_dialog_ready_callback` which finally calls `trust_prompt_show`.

I also found that the "Calendar authentication request" dialog comes from EDS but I couldn't find the missing link between Gnome Calendar and said dialog.

Technically, the dialogs could easily be ported to libadwaita in EDS but I don't think this will be wanted. I filed evolution-data-server#573 to discuss a path forward to fix those dialogs on mobile.

Thanks! I can confirm that everything is fixed now. I'm so happy to see this part of the updated event editor design getting implemented.

@feaneron In my opinion this MR is ready from a functional and design perspective. Regarding the unchecked bullet points of @jfft in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/-/merge_requests/505#note_2259945: 

* The checkmark is default for ComboRows and should be kept in my opinion also because it will probably not be possible to remove it in the future anyway.
* The eye-not-looking symbolic as the calendar visibility indicator has been ported and it looks fine as shown in my screenshots above. If we want to address this again, we should do it in a separate issue in my opinion and consider all places where calendar visibility is displayed or can be toggled together.
* The calendar names ellipsize after a reasonable length now.

note.body:
I have tested your branch again:

* [x] The calendar name label of the combo row shouldn't be dimmed.
* [x] The labels in the popover shouldn't be dimmed.

![grafik.png](/uploads/4e137c731553cf36ae4a7436cf5af9b8/grafik.png){width="50%"}

---

* [x] The combo row title should not wrap. Set wrap=false for the combo row title.

| wrap=true | wrap=false |
|-----------|------------|
| ![Bildschirmfoto vom 2024-11-04 21-15-15.png](/uploads/1e3b4ac7d325ed0934b3b737a6f81dfb/Bildschirmfoto_vom_2024-11-04_21-15-15.png) | ![Bildschirmfoto vom 2024-11-04 21-26-58.png](/uploads/2584138c1ea8b808d9f1ef78086da961/Bildschirmfoto_vom_2024-11-04_21-26-58.png) |

note.body:
If I remember correctly the reason we didn’t go with the filled/hollow circle for indicating visibility was that it could be misunderstood as the list selection check mark itself. This was only a problem because by then the list didn’t have a checkmark indicating the selected item. Now that the context of the dropdown has changed and we have the default combo row checkmark I’d be fine with the filled/hollow circles approach.

So it would look like this but with the default combo row checkmark next to the selected calendar:

![image.png](/uploads/9d0127d133e216aaa7dc3a560915938e/image.png)

The checkmark being aligned with the label is also a default. It does not look good with the eye icon and checkmark next to each other of course. In my opinion this could be improved upon in a follow up MR when we have a better design. I would like to avoid having this MR being blocked on that detail as it fixes some more serious bug (#1299).

note.body:
Functional feedback from doing a quick test of the branch:

* [ ] This introduces a checkmark for the currently selected calendar;  
I'm not sure that is actually needed here, and it might clash with other parts of the UI  
(ex.: the same checkmark meaning something different in the sidebar's calendars list popovermenu widget, and the eye icons).  
I'd think it would make more sense to hide the currently selected item from the dropdown (#68) if possible.

* [ ] The "eye-not-looking" / "view-conceal-symbolic" icon for hidden calendars, implemented in !477, is missing.  
Please port that functionality to your branch.  
(It was the result of a _very_ lengthy and extensive design consensus process)

* [ ] It seems to ellipsize calendar names too much,  
as seen in the screenshot below:  
![image](/uploads/dc2f0e0b372cbdb93d126b4417ac3b37/image.png)  
(I would tend to think they should not be ellisized at all unless they exceed the available screen width)

> I don't have Evolution installed, don't see why that should be a requirement.

Well, it is a requirement for you now—if anything to solve your immediate issue on your side (and you can always uninstall the Evolution GUI app afterwards) and for the sake of testing whether my diagnosis above is correct—because this UI is not implemented anywhere else at the moment (until someone offers a design and patch for it).

target_title: No GUI to specify which addressbooks are used to show contacts' birthdays in automatic birthdays calendar

note.body:
Indeed, my suspicion is that you have not marked that other (online) addressbook as being a source for birthdays in Evolution Data Server, so you would need to right-click that addressbook in Evolution's GUI and change that property, a bit like this:

![image](/uploads/7af5498a40572e4ba9aa1d6e58eed7bd/image.png)

Presumably that is your problem? I can't imagine another explanation.

In any case, this makes me realize that we have no UI anywhere in GNOME Contacts (or GOA's initial connection UI for that account) to do this kind of thing (and I don't think GNOME Calendar would be the right place for such a UI, since it does not manage any contacts, at least until we have meetings invitations management). @nielsdg, could we consider this a shortcoming issue of both GOA and GNOME Contacts, and move it primarily to GNOME Contacts as a feature request?

* the properties of the addressbook in Evolution to ensure birthdays are activated for it.

target_title: CalDAV webcalendars added via URLs get prompted for username and password three times per calendar

note.body:
Correct. If you want to share the credentials, then create a WebDAV based collection account and it'll use the credentials across all the calendars under that account. It also auto-detects the WebDAV collections, thus it can add all the CalDAV and CardDAV collections in a single shot. That auto-addition is probably not that useful for the gnome-calendar though. The collection accounts can have particular parts disabled (mail/calendar/contacts).

If you had been repeatedly asked for the credentials for a single calendar, then it probably failed to connect to it.

note.body:
What I tried:

* Signal Connection Verification: Ensured that the signal connection for row-activated is set correctly in the code.
* Debug Print Statements: Added numerous debug print statements throughout the initialization and signal handling functions to verify the flow of control and check variable states.
* Manual Popover Display: Attempted to manually trigger the popover display to confirm it renders correctly.
* UI Loading Validation: Checked if the UI file is loaded correctly and if the listbox is populated with the expected calendar data.
* Minimal Test Cases: Considered creating a minimal test case to isolate the popover and listbox functionality for debugging purposes.

Expected Behavior: When a user activates a row in the calendar listbox, the following should occur:
* The signal handler select_calendar_and_close_popover should be triggered.
* The selected calendar should be printed to the console (or updated in the UI).
* The popover should close after selecting a calendar.

target_title: Calendars list picker popover widget in Event Editor dialog does not close when making a selection

note.body:
I am working on this issue […]. Current State: Despite implementing the necessary code and following the expected design, the following issues are occurring:

* Popover and listbox interaction:

  * The GtkListBox that contains the calendar options is not functioning as intended.  
Specifically, when a row is activated, the connected signal handler (select_calendar_and_close_popover) does not seem to be triggered.

  * Debugging print statements indicate that the row-activated signal is not firing, leading to the conclusion that there may be an issue with the signal connection or the way the listbox is populated.
* UI Initialization:
  * The UI is loaded from an XML file using gtk_builder_add_from_file, but there is uncertainty if the UI elements are correctly instantiated.
  * The listbox appears to be initialized, but checks show that the expected calendar data is not being correctly associated with each row.

Timezone is wrong in GNOME Calendar, but not in GNOME notification area

note.body:
Hi, I'm experiencing the same issue on Fedora 40 Calendar 46.1 - gnome calendar displays it as if it was UTC0 time (2 hours ahead for me)

I suspect it might be related to the `X-WR-TIMEZONE`. My calendar file doesn't have the standard `VTIMEZONE` instead it only uses the extension `X-WR-TIMEZONE`. I suspect gnome calendar isn't taking it into account. When searching throught the source code you have many references to `VTIMEZONE` but none to `X-WR-TIMEZONE` I don't know why gnome shell displays it correctly though.
